ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The SRW Cogeneration, L.P. (SRWCLP) facility is owned by Conoco Global Power Development ? Sabine Inc., general partner and Conoco Global Power Assets ? Sabine Inc., limited partner, which are subsidiaries of parent company ConocoPhillips Company and is operated and maintained by the E.I. DuPont De Nemours and Company.  The Dun & Bradstreet number for ConocoPhillips is 001368265.  The Cogeneration unit is located within the DuPont Sabine River Works (DuPont) facility.  The SRWCLP facility has a contract with DuPont to operate and maintain the Cogen unit and for shared services.  The daily onsite management oversight is the responsibility of the Operations & Maintenance Director, who is an employee of SRWCLP.  All safety-related activities applicable to the Cogeneration unit are in compliance with the corporate policies of DuPont.  These policies can be summarized as follows:



* All safety and environmental incidents are preventable.

* The Goal is Zero.  Zero injuries and zero incidents.



Corporate policies are embodied in the numerous Safety, Health, Environmental, and Engineering Standards which apply globally.  At this facility the policies are implemented through the site Safety, Health, and Environmental Manual and the Process Safety Management Manual.





DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The SRWCLP facility is located within the boundaries of the DuPont SRW facility, which is located approximately 2 miles south of the city of Orange, TX in a rural setting on FM 1006.  The Dupont facility is located on 1,500 acres, which is divided between chemical process units, the employee recreation area, and bio-oxidation ponds.  The SRWCLP facility is located in between the DuPont and INVISTA process units on the North side of the DuPont facility.  The chemical facility is secure by chain link fence, video cameras, controlled entry, and a 24-hour security force.



The C

ogeneration unit is a dual train gas-fired combustion turbine cogeneration plant that produces steam and electricity.  The duct burners on the combustion turbine units have selective catalytic reduction (SCR) equipment to reduce the nitrogen oxide (NOX) emissions.  Aqueous Ammonia (28 wt. %) is vaporized and injected into the duct burner exhaust.  The ammonia is a reagent in the SCR to reduce the NOX as the exhaust gases flow across a solid catalyst bed.



The aqueous ammonia is stored on site in a single storage tank.  The total capacity of the ammonia storage tank and feed system exceeds the threshold quantity for applicability to 40 CFR Part 68, the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation.  There are no other toxic or flammable materials on site that exceed the RMP threshold values.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The SRWCLP facility is subject to OPA-90 40 CFR 112 and the state of Texas EPCRA regulations as noted in section 9.8 of this RMP.  The SRWCLP facility implements management systems and practices that meet or exceed RMP Level 2 Prevention Program requirements to comply with these regulations.  The Cogeneration unit is not subject to 29 CFR 1910-119, the Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard because the aqueous ammonia concentration (28 wt. %) is below the PSM threshold of 44 wt. %.   



Prevention Program 2 requirements are defined according to the following elements:



* Safety information;

* Hazard review;

* Operating procedures;

* Training;

* Maintenance;

* Compliance audits; and

* Incident investigation.



DuPont personnel operating and maintaining the SRWCLP facility conduct their activities under the requirements of the safety programs of the DuPont SRW facility.



The SRWCLP and DuPont SRW safety programs include:



1.  Designing for Safety

* A documented process technology system that covers materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.

* Accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategic

ally located.

* Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.

* Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.



2. Maintaining our Plant

* Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.

* Contractors are trained and qualified.

* A work permit system controls hazards.



3. Operating Safely

* Operators are trained and job qualified.

* Technical resources are available and utilized as required.

* Operators follow approved procedures.



4. Auditing our Operations

* Routine safety inspections are conducted.

* Corporate, independent, and governmental audits and reviews are conducted.

* Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

* Safety critical equipment is subjected to periodic testing and inspection to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.

* Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting any new or modified equipment.

* Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design applications.

* All incidents are investigated and actions are taken to prevent recurrence.



Safety is a job requirement for all employees and contractors.





CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The aqueous ammonia system has been designed to meet or exceed the design standards aqueous ammonia storage and handling systems.  A detailed hazard and operability study (HAZOP) was originally conducted to verify design and operational safety, and to identify the potential for safety enhancements.  There is a Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) review, which is ongoing at this time.  As in the previous HAZOP, the analysis includes the delivery and unloading of aqueous ammonia to the storage tank, as well as storage, pumping, vaporization, and injection.



The aqueous ammonia system is subject to preventative maintenance inspections and testing to ensure its ongoing integrity.  Future system modifications will be controlled under a strict management of change (MOC) program to ensure the appropriate design standards a

re applied.  The MOC procedures ensure that proper hazard review is conducted; training is performed; and operating, maintenance, and emergency response procedures are kept up to date.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



To date, there have been no reportable releases of aqueous ammonia.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM





The facility maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker health and public safety.  The program is also coordinated with the community response plan maintained by the Orange County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).  The facility Emergency Response (ER) Plan has procedures for responding to all types of emergency situations, including the release of aqueous ammonia.  The ER Plan covers all aspects of emergency response such as, first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and personnel accounting during and after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.



Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to the release of aqueous ammonia.  This program can be summarized as follows:



Training and Preparation

* All plant personnel receive emergency response training.

* Plant emergency responders are trained to control releases.

* Emergency response plans are current.

* The plant participates in emergency drills.

* Critiques are conducted on drills and actual emergency response events.





If a Major Release Occurs

* The emergency alarm is activated.

* The plant Emergency Operating Center is activated.

* The plant Incident Commander and Emergency Response Team respond.

* The Community Alert System is activated.

* Outside emergency personnel are notified as appropriate.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



* Continuous improvement in the safety program as a result of audits, inspections, incident investigations, etc.

* The continued goal of ?zero? safety and environmental incidents.
